discovery_rules.name: Network Interfaces Discovery
discovery_rules.description:
Discovering interfaces from IF-MIB. Interfaces are not discovered:
- with down(2) Administrative status
- with notPresent(6) Operational status
- loopbacks

item_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFDESCR}: Inbound packets discarded
item_prototypes.description:
MIB: IF-MIB
The number of inbound packets which were chosen to be discarded
even though no errors had been detected to prevent their being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol.
One possible reason for discarding such a packet could be to free up buffer space.
Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system,
and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFDESCR}: Inbound packets with errors
item_prototypes.description:
MIB: IF-MIB
For packet-oriented interfaces, the number of inbound packets that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol.  For character-oriented or fixed-length interfaces, the number of inbound transmission units that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFDESCR}: Bits received
item_prototypes.description:
MIB: IF-MIB
The total number of octets received on the interface,including framing characters. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occurat re-initialization of the management system, and atother times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFDESCR}: Outbound packets discarded
item_prototypes.description:
MIB: IF-MIB
The number of outbound packets which were chosen to be discarded
even though no errors had been detected to prevent their being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol.
One possible reason for discarding such a packet could be to free up buffer space.
Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system,
and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFDESCR}: Outbound packets with errors
item_prototypes.description:
MIB: IF-MIB
For packet-oriented interfaces, the number of outbound packets that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol.  For character-oriented or fixed-length interfaces, the number of outbound transmission units that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFDESCR}: Bits sent
item_prototypes.description:
MIB: IF-MIB
The total number of octets transmitted out of the interface, including framing characters. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occurat re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFDESCR}: Speed
item_prototypes.description:
MIB: IF-MIB
An estimate of the interface's current bandwidth in bits per second.
For interfaces which do not vary in bandwidth or for those where no accurate estimation can be made,
this object should contain the nominal bandwidth.
If the bandwidth of the interface is greater than the maximum value reportable by this object then
this object should report its maximum value (4,294,967,295) and ifHighSpeed must be used to report the interace's speed.
For a sub-layer which has no concept of bandwidth, this object should be zero.

item_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFDESCR}: Operational status
item_prototypes.description:
MIB: IF-MIB
The current operational state of the interface.
- The testing(3) state indicates that no operational packet scan be passed
- If ifAdminStatus is down(2) then ifOperStatus should be down(2)
- If ifAdminStatus is changed to up(1) then ifOperStatus should change to up(1) if the interface is ready to transmit and receive network traffic
- It should change todormant(5) if the interface is waiting for external actions (such as a serial line waiting for an incoming connection)
- It should remain in the down(2) state if and only if there is a fault that prevents it from going to the up(1) state
- It should remain in the notPresent(6) state if the interface has missing(typically, hardware) components.

trigger_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFDESCR}: Link down
trigger_prototypes.description:
Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}.
Interface is down

item_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFDESCR}: Interface type
item_prototypes.description:
MIB: IF-MIB
The type of interface.
Additional values for ifType are assigned by the Internet Assigned NumbersAuthority (IANA),
through updating the syntax of the IANAifType textual convention.

trigger_prototypes.expression:
change(/10.16.7.67/net.if.speed[ifSpeed.{#SNMPINDEX}])<0 and last(/10.16.7.67/net.if.speed[ifSpeed.{#SNMPINDEX}])>0
and (
last(/10.16.7.67/net.if.type[ifType.{#SNMPINDEX}])=6 or
last(/10.16.7.67/net.if.type[ifType.{#SNMPINDEX}])=7 or
last(/10.16.7.67/net.if.type[ifType.{#SNMPINDEX}])=11 or
last(/10.16.7.67/net.if.type[ifType.{#SNMPINDEX}])=62 or
last(/10.16.7.67/net.if.type[ifType.{#SNMPINDEX}])=69 or
last(/10.16.7.67/net.if.type[ifType.{#SNMPINDEX}])=117
)
and
(last(/10.16.7.67/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}])<>2)
trigger_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFDESCR}: Ethernet has changed to lower speed than it was before
trigger_prototypes.description:
Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}.
This Ethernet connection has transitioned down from its known maximum speed. This might be a sign of autonegotiation issues. Ack to close.

trigger_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFDESCR}: High bandwidth usage >{$IF_UTIL_MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}%
trigger_prototypes.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}.

trigger_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFDESCR}: High error rate
trigger_prototypes.description:
Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}.
Recovers when below 80% of {$IF_ERRORS_WARN:"{#IFNAME}"} threshold

items.description: It could be increased by using sysctrl utility or modifying file /etc/sysctl.conf.

triggers.name: Configured max number of open filedescriptors is too low (< {$KERNEL.MAXFILES.MIN})

items.name: Maximum number of processes
items.description: It could be increased by using sysctrl utility or modifying file /etc/sysctl.conf.

triggers.name: Configured max number of processes is too low (< {$KERNEL.MAXPROC.MIN})

dependencies.name: Getting closer to process limit (over 80% used)

items.name: CPU utilization
items.description: CPU utilization in %

triggers.name: High CPU utilization (over {$CPU.UTIL.CRIT}% for 5m)
triggers.description: CPU utilization is too high. The system might be slow to respond.

dependencies.name: Load average is too high (per CPU load over {$LOAD_AVG_PER_CPU.MAX.WARN} for 5m)

items.name: CPU guest time
items.description: Guest  time (time  spent  running  a  virtual  CPU  for  a  guest  operating  system)

items.name: CPU guest nice time
items.description: Time spent running a niced guest (virtual CPU for guest operating systems under the control of the Linux kernel)

items.name: CPU idle time
items.description: The time the CPU has spent doing nothing.

items.name: CPU interrupt time
items.description: The amount of time the CPU has been servicing hardware interrupts.

items.name: CPU iowait time
items.description: Amount of time the CPU has been waiting for I/O to complete.

items.name: CPU nice time
items.description: The time the CPU has spent running users' processes that have been niced.

items.name: CPU softirq time
items.description: The amount of time the CPU has been servicing software interrupts.

items.name: CPU steal time
items.description: The amount of CPU 'stolen' from this virtual machine by the hypervisor for other tasks (such as running another virtual machine).

items.name: CPU system time
items.description: The time the CPU has spent running the kernel and its processes.

items.name: CPU user time
items.description: The time the CPU has spent running users' processes that are not niced.

items.name: System name
items.description: System host name.

triggers.name: System name has changed (new name: {ITEM.VALUE})
triggers.description: System name has changed. Ack to close.

items.name: System local time
items.description: System local time of the host.

triggers.name: System time is out of sync (diff with Zabbix server > {$SYSTEM.FUZZYTIME.MAX}s)
triggers.description: The host system time is different from the Zabbix server time.

items.name: Operating system architecture
items.description: Operating system architecture of the host.

triggers.name: Operating system description has changed
triggers.description: Operating system description has changed. Possible reasons that system has been updated or replaced. Ack to close.

triggers.description: The host uptime is less than 10 minutes

items.name: Number of logged in users
items.description: Number of users who are currently logged in.

items.name: Available memory
items.description: Available memory, in Linux, available = free + buffers + cache. On other platforms calculation may vary. See also: https://www.zabbix.com/documentation/current/manual/appendix/items/vm.memory.size_params

items.name: Available memory in %
items.description: Available memory as percentage of total. See also: https://www.zabbix.com/documentation/current/manual/appendix/items/vm.memory.size_params

triggers.description: The system is running out of free memory.

items.name: Zabbix agent availability

triggers.name: Zabbix agent is not available (for {$AGENT.TIMEOUT})
triggers.description: For passive only agents, host availability is used with {$AGENT.TIMEOUT} as time threshold.

item_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFNAME}: Operational status
item_prototypes.description:
Indicates the interface RFC2863 operational state as a string.
Possible values are:"unknown", "notpresent", "down", "lowerlayerdown", "testing","dormant", "up".
Reference: https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/ABI/testing/sysfs-class-net

trigger_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFNAME}: Link down
trigger_prototypes.description:
This trigger expression works as follows:
1. Can be triggered if operations status is down.
2. {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 - user can redefine Context macro to value - 0. That marks this interface as not important. No new trigger will be fired if this interface is down.
3. {TEMPLATE_NAME:METRIC.diff()}=1) - trigger fires only if operational status was up(1) sometime before. (So, do not fire 'ethernal off' interfaces.)

WARNING: if closed manually - won't fire again on next poll, because of .diff.

item_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFNAME}: Interface type
item_prototypes.description:
Indicates the interface protocol type as a decimal value.
See include/uapi/linux/if_arp.h for all possible values.
Reference: https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/ABI/testing/sysfs-class-net

trigger_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFNAME}: Ethernet has changed to lower speed than it was before
trigger_prototypes.description: This Ethernet connection has transitioned down from its known maximum speed. This might be a sign of autonegotiation issues. Ack to close.

trigger_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFNAME}: High error rate ( > {$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"} for 5m)
trigger_prototypes.description: Recovers when below 80% of {$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"} threshold

item_prototypes.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk average queue size (avgqu-sz)
item_prototypes.description: Current average disk queue, the number of requests outstanding on the disk at the time the performance data is collected.

item_prototypes.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk read request avg waiting time (r_await)
item_prototypes.description: This formula contains two boolean expressions that evaluates to 1 or 0 in order to set calculated metric to zero and to avoid division by zero exception.

item_prototypes.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk read rate
item_prototypes.description: r/s. The number (after merges) of read requests completed per second for the device.

item_prototypes.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk read time (rate)
item_prototypes.description: Rate of total read time counter. Used in r_await calculation

item_prototypes.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk utilization
item_prototypes.description: This item is the percentage of elapsed time that the selected disk drive was busy servicing read or writes requests.

item_prototypes.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk write request avg waiting time (w_await)
item_prototypes.description: This formula contains two boolean expressions that evaluates to 1 or 0 in order to set calculated metric to zero and to avoid division by zero exception.

item_prototypes.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk write rate
item_prototypes.description: w/s. The number (after merges) of write requests completed per second for the device.

item_prototypes.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk write time (rate)
item_prototypes.description: Rate of total write time counter. Used in w_await calculation

item_prototypes.name: {#DEVNAME}: Get stats
item_prototypes.description: Get contents of /sys/block/{#DEVNAME}/stat for disk stats.

trigger_prototypes.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk read/write request responses are too high (read > {$VFS.DEV.READ.AWAIT.WARN:"{#DEVNAME}"} ms for 15m or write > {$VFS.DEV.WRITE.AWAIT.WARN:"{#DEVNAME}"} ms for 15m)
trigger_prototypes.description: This trigger might indicate disk {#DEVNAME} saturation.

discovery_rules.name: Mounted filesystem discovery
discovery_rules.description: Discovery of file systems of different types.

trigger_prototypes.name: {#FSNAME}: Running out of free inodes (free < {$VFS.FS.INODE.PFREE.MIN.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"}%)
trigger_prototypes.description:
It may become impossible to write to disk if there are no index nodes left.
As symptoms, 'No space left on device' or 'Disk is full' errors may be seen even though free space is available.

trigger_prototypes.name: {#FSNAME}: Running out of free inodes (free < {$VFS.FS.INODE.PFREE.MIN.WARN:"{#FSNAME}"}%)
trigger_prototypes.description:
It may become impossible to write to disk if there are no index nodes left.
As symptoms, 'No space left on device' or 'Disk is full' errors may be seen even though free space is available.

item_prototypes.name: {#FSNAME}: Space utilization
item_prototypes.description: Space utilization in % for {#FSNAME}

item_prototypes.name: {#FSNAME}: Total space
item_prototypes.description: Total space in Bytes

item_prototypes.name: {#FSNAME}: Used space
item_prototypes.description: Used storage in Bytes

trigger_prototypes.name: {#FSNAME}: Disk space is critically low (used > {$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"}%)
trigger_prototypes.description:
Two conditions should match: First, space utilization should be above {$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"}.
 Second condition should be one of the following:
 - The disk free space is less than 5G.
 - The disk will be full in less than 24 hours.

trigger_prototypes.name: {#FSNAME}: Disk space is low (used > {$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.WARN:"{#FSNAME}"}%)
trigger_prototypes.description:
Two conditions should match: First, space utilization should be above {$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.WARN:"{#FSNAME}"}.
 Second condition should be one of the following:
 - The disk free space is less than 10G.
 - The disk will be full in less than 24 hours.

trigger_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFNAME}: Link down

This trigger expression works as follows:
1. Can be triggered if operations status is down.
2. {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 - user can redefine Context macro to value - 0. That marks this interface as not important. No new trigger will be fired if this interface is down.
3. {TEMPLATE_NAME:METRIC.diff()}=1) - trigger fires only if operational status was up(1) sometime before. (So, do not fire 'ethernal off' interfaces.)

WARNING: if closed manually - won't fire again on next poll, because of .diff.

Two conditions should match: First, space utilization should be above {$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"}.
